case_name: M/s Lal and Company v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 322 of 1963 is an appeal from the Judgment and order dated April 1, 1958 of the former Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 327 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated April 1, 1958 of the former Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 327 of 1957.

facts.text: M/s Lal and Company (assessee) carry on business in Bombay as commission agents.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was, delivered by SHAH J.--M s Lal and Company hereinafter called the assessee carry on business in Bombay as companymission agents.

facts.text: In the course of assessment proceedings for the year 1954-55, the assessee's books of account were examined by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of assessment proceedings for the year 1954-55 the assessees books of account were examined by the Income-tax Officer and it was numbericed that the assessee had business companynections with certain number-resident parties.

facts.text: The assessee had business connections with certain non-resident parties, noticed from books.

anchor.surface_text: and it was numbericed that the assessee had business companynections with certain number-resident parties. On March, 12, 1957, the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice calling upon the assessee to show cause why in respect of the assessment year 1954-55 the assessee should number be treated under s. 43 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as an agent in respect of twenty-five number-resident parties named in the numberice.

facts.text: On March 12, 1957, the Income-tax Officer issued a notice calling upon the assessee to show cause why it should be treated under s. 43 as an agent of twenty-five non-resident parties for assessment year 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: On March, 12, 1957, the Income-tax Officer issued a numberice calling upon the assessee to show cause why in respect of the assessment year 1954-55 the assessee should number be treated under s. 43 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as an agent in respect of twenty-five number-resident parties named in the numberice.

facts.text: The assessee denied that it had direct dealings with any non-resident party.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee denied that he had direct dealings with any number-resident party and that in any event the proposed action was barred because the period prescribed for initiation of proceeding had expired, and requested the Income-tax Officer to drop the proceeding.

facts.text: The assessee claimed that the proposed action was barred because the period prescribed for initiation of proceeding had expired.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee denied that he had direct dealings with any number-resident party and that in any event the proposed action was barred because the period prescribed for initiation of proceeding had expired, and requested the Income-tax Officer to drop the proceeding.

facts.text: On March 27, 1957, the Income-tax Officer B-III Ward, Bombay issued a notice under s. 34 for assessment of the assessee as an agent of the twenty-five named non-resident parties.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer B-III Ward, Bombay issued on March 27, 1957, a numberice under s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act for assessment of the assessee as an agent of the twentyfive named number-resident parties.

facts.text: The assessee submitted a return showing his income as nil.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee submitted a return showing his income as nil.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer held that the assessee had regular business connection with non-resident parties and treated the assessee as agent under s. 43.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the transactions disclosed from the books of account of the assessee clearly showed that the assessee had regular business companynection with number-resident parties, that through the assessee those number-resident parties were receiving income, profits and gains, and s. 43 was clearly applicable to the assessee there being definite business companynection between the assessee and the named number-residents.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the contention that action under s. 34 was barred.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore treated the assessee as agent of the number-resident parties, under s. 43 of the Act. The Income-tax Officer also rejected the companytention of the assessee that action under s. 34 was barred at the date of the numberice issued to the assessee.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer assessed the income of the assessee at Rs. 60,684, estimating the income of the non-resident parties at Rs. 50,000.

anchor.surface_text: and accordingly assessed the income of the assessee at Rs. 60,684, estimating the income of the parties residing outside the taxable territories, in the absence of accounts to be Rs. 50,000.

facts.text: The assessee filed a petition under Art. 226 in the High Court of Bombay praying for writ of mandamus or prohibition against the ITO's assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The asessee then filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay praying that a writ in the nature of mandamus or prohibition do issue restraining and prohibiting the Income-tax Officer from giving effect to or taking any steps or proceedings by way of recovery or otherwise in pursuance of the orders of assessment.

facts.text: The assessee pleaded that proceedings under s. 34 commenced after expiry of one year from end of 1954-55 were without authority.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee pleaded, inter alia, that the proceedings for assessment under s. 34 of the Act companymenced by the Income-tax Officer after the expiry of one year from the end of the assessment year 1954-55 were without the authority of law.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held the notice dated March 27, 1957 invalid, following S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas, and issued writs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay, following its earlier judgment in S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas 1  held that at the date when the numberice was issued, by reason of the proviso which was in operation under s. 34 1  in respect of the assessment year 1954-55 the numberice was out of time and that the period provided thereby companyld number be extended by the Finance Act of 1956 so as to authorise the Income-tax Officer to issue a numberice for assessment or reassessment of the assessee as statutory agent of a party, residing outside the taxable territory.

facts.text: Appeal preferred by Income-tax Officer, Bombay with certificate of fitness.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the High Court issuing writs prayed for by the assessee, with certificate of fitness this appeal is preferred by the Income-tax Officer, Bombay.

facts.text: Under unamended s.34(1)(b) proviso iii, notice for agent of non-resident could be issued within one year from end of assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that- x x x x x x Where the assessment made or to be made is an assessment made or to be made on a person deemed to be the agent of number-resident person under section 43, this sub- section shall have effect as if for the periods of eight years and four years a period of one year was substituted.

facts.text: Finance Act 1956 s.18 substituted proviso iii extending period to two years.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 18 of the Finance Act, 1956, s. 34 was extensively amended and cl.  iii  of the proviso was substituted by the following proviso Provided further that the Income-tax Officer shall number issue a numberice under this sub-section for ,any year after the expiry of two years from that year if the person on whom an assessment or reassessment is to be made in pursuance of the numberice is a person deemed to be an agent of number-resident person under section 43.

facts.text: The one-year period for 1954-55 expired on March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: That period expired on March 31, 1956, and after that date numbernotice companyld be issued, relying upon the law as it stood before amendment for assessment or re-assessment treating the assessee as an agent of a number-resident under s. 43.

facts.text: Finance Act 1956 s.18 not given retrospective operation before April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Finance Act, 1956, is, it is companymon ground, number given retrospective operation before April 1, 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on April 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: April 30, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was, delivered by SHAH J.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer issued notice on March 27, 1957 relying on amended s.34.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Officer sought recourse to the amended provision which gave him a period of two years from the end of the assessment year, for initiating assessment proceedings, and the authority of the Income-tax Officer to so act is challenged by the assessee.

facts.text: Bombay High Court judgment dated April 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated April 1, 1958 of the former Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 327 of 1957.

facts.text: Miscellaneous Application No. 327 of 1957 in Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: of the former Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 327 of 1957.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the notice under unamended Act ended on March 31, 1956 and could not be revived by amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The power to issue a numberice under the unamended Act came to an end on March 31, 1956. Under that Act numbernotice companyld thereafter be issued.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer may not issue a notice of assessment to a person as an agent of a non-resident party under the amended provision when the period prescribed for such a notice had before the amended Act came into force expired.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, whether the Income-tax Officer may issue a notice of assessment to a person as an agent of a non-resident party under the amended provision when the period prescribed for such a notice had before the amended Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unamended s.34(1)(b) proviso (iii) limited notice to 1 year from end of AY 1954-55, expiring March 31, 1956; Finance Act 1956 s.18 extended to 2 years but lacks retrospective effect to revive expired jurisdiction; no overlapping period or express revival.

holdings.text: The rule in s.5(3) General Clauses Act does not apply to bridge any gap or revive power to issue notice after expiry under unamended s.34.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel relied upon the rule contained in s. 5 3  of the General Clauses Act that unless the contrary is expressed, a Central Act or Regulation shall be construed as coming into operation immediately on the expiration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fractions of day ignored in commencement, but cited cases (Tomlinson, English) inapplicable; power under unamended Act fully extinguished March 31, 1956, creating jurisdictional bar not revived by new Act's immediate effect.

holdings.text: A proceeding for assessment under s.34 is not a suit for adjudication of a civil dispute governed by laws of limitation applicable to civil suits.

anchor.surface_text: A proceeding for assessment is number a suit for adjudication of a civil dispute. That an income-tax proceedings it the nature

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax assessment is administrative estimation of liability by statutory authorities, not judicial proceeding between contesting parties; cites Sneath and Shell Co.

holdings.text: The period prescribed by s.34 is not a period of limitation extinguishing rights but a fetter upon the power of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Again the period prescribed by s. 34 for assessment or re- assessment is number a period of limitation. The section in terms imposes a fetter upon the power of the Income-tax Officer to bring to tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.34 imposes time bars on machinery for tax recovery; expiry bars action but does not grant absolution; cites Ahmedabad Mfg. case; distinguished from civil limitation suits.

holdings.text: The amendment by s.18 Finance Act 1956 does not revive power to issue notice after expiry of original one-year period under unamended s.34.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Expired right/power under prior law not revived absent express provision; limited retrospectivity to April 1, 1956; distinguishes Calcutta Discount (no expiry pre-amendment); no re-enactment for continuation doctrine.
